subject: Re: Which lexical set is the second vowel of _because_ in?
msgSnippet: ... Replying to both John and Paul (last two messages). The hard_basket will be uploaded maybe next week or two.  At the moment it only has the word
messageBody:
>
> I've created a file "hard_basket" in my intQS project where I shall
> put words that I don't know what to do with.
>

Replying to both John and Paul (last two messages).

The "hard_basket" will be uploaded maybe next week or two. At the
moment it only has the word _because_ in it. Any word I put it in
this file will be words that I need suggestions from others to help
classify it.


Some words have two or more different pronunciations distinct enough
that I argue that it belongs in two or more different lexical sets and
is thus spelt two different ways. eg: _again_ is spelt
'Utter+Gay+Et+No' and also 'Utter+Gay+Eight+No'
However there have been a few other words for which it seems clear
enough to me that they are of a certain lexical set but that it has an
unusual pronunciation in some accent with respect to its set. eg: I
would say that _of_ is a LOT set since in RP it is /Qv/ and GA has a
pronunciation /A:v/ (LOT typically has RP-/Q/ and GA-/A/): but there
is also a very common (apparently the most common GA according to
Longman's) GA pronunciation /Vv/. LOT doesn't not normally have a /V/
option for GA- but in this case I would say that it is still a LOT
word but with one extra unusual pronunciation. The word _from_ is
very similar: RP->/frQm/, GA->/frVm, frQm/. So far out of a couple of
hundred there have only been three words- _of_, _from_ and _part_ that
have an odd pronunciation. I have only given these words one
international spelling but noted the fact that they have non-standard
pronunciations with-respect-to their lexical set in the spreadsheet. I
haven't included these in the "hard_basket".

There are also a few words that I have given two spellings for when
according to the rules in the proposal it is arguable that they should
only have one. These are words that have had some vowel commonly
replaced by a schwa. Such has nobody: pronunciation 1)/n@UbQdi/ - has
/Q/ vowel pronunciation and 2)/n@Ub@di/(the most common pronunciation
according to Longman's)- where /Q/ has been replaced by /@/. I've
listed two spellings for _nobody_ based on these two pronunciations.
The others like this so far are: _anybody_, _anyone_, _anything_,
somebody. In the future I might reduce it to just one spelling.
